The above described method(s), process(es), or technique(s) may include various acts, though those of skill in the art will appreciate that in alternative examples certain acts may be omitted and/or additional acts may be added. Those of skill in the art will appreciate that the illustrated order of the acts is shown for exemplary purposes only and may change in alternative examples. Some of the exemplary acts or operations of the above described method(s), process(es), or technique(s) are performed iteratively. Some acts of the above described method(s), process(es), or technique(s) may be performed during each iteration, after a plurality of iterations, or at the end of all the iterations.

The above description of illustrated implementations, including what is described in the Abstract, is not intended to be exhaustive or to limit the implementations to the precise forms disclosed. Although specific implementations of and examples are described herein for illustrative purposes, various equivalent modifications may be made without departing from the spirit and scope of the disclosure, as will be recognized by those skilled in the relevant art. The teachings provided herein of the various implementations may be applied to other methods of quantum computation, not necessarily the exemplary methods for quantum computation generally described above.

The various implementations described above may be combined to provide further implementations. All of the commonly assigned US patent application publications, US patent applications, foreign patents, and foreign patent applications referred to in this specification and/or listed in the Application Data Sheet are incorporated herein by reference, in their entirety, including but not limited to: U.S. Pat. Nos. 8,441,330; 8,247,799; 7,687,938; U.S. Provisional Patent Application No. 62,760,253; U.S. Provisional Patent Application No. 62/944,143; and U.S. Non-Provisional patent application Ser. No. 16/481,788.

These and other changes may be made to the implementations in light of the above-detailed description. In general, in the following claims, the terms used should not be construed to limit the claims to the specific implementations disclosed in the specification and the claims but should be construed to include all possible implementations along with the full scope of equivalents to which such claims are entitled. Accordingly, the claims are not limited by the disclosure.

claim.claim-text: 1. A method for mitigating flux trapping in a superconducting integrated circuit, the method comprising:forming a first device, the first device comprising at least a portion of a first metal layer within the superconducting integrated circuit, the first metal layer comprising a first superconducting material having a first critical temperature; andforming a flux-directing layer comprising a second superconducting material having a second critical temperature;wherein the first superconducting material and the second superconducting material are selected such that as the superconducting integrated circuit is cooled from a first temperature that is greater than both the first critical temperature and the second critical temperature to a second temperature that is less than both the first critical temperature and the second critical temperature, a relative temperature difference between the first critical temperature and the second critical temperature causes the flux-directing layer to direct flux away from the first device and towards a flux-trapping location spaced from the first device, the flux becoming trapped at the flux-trapping location and isolated from the first device as the superconducting integrated circuit is cooled.

2. The method of claim 1, wherein forming a flux-directing layer includes forming a flux-directing layer positioned in flux-transmitting communication with the flux-trapping location, and wherein causing the flux-directing layer to direct flux away from the first device and towards a flux-trapping location includes causing the flux-directing layer to direct flux into the flux-trapping location.
3. The method of claim 2, further comprising forming a flux-trapping aperture at the flux-trapping location.

4. The method of claim 3, wherein forming a flux-trapping aperture at the flux-trapping location comprises forming one of a parallel-piped opening and a trough within the superconducting integrated circuit at the flux-trapping location.
5. The method of claim 2, further comprising forming shielding to enclose the flux-trapping location.
6. The method of claim 5, wherein forming shielding to enclose the flux-trapping location comprises forming a plurality of superconducting stud vias within the superconducting integrated circuit.
7. The method of claim 3, wherein forming a flux-directing layer comprises depositing a superconducting metal layer comprising an opening aligned with the flux-trapping aperture.
8. The method of claim 1, wherein forming a first device comprises forming a first device as one of a qubit and a coupler.

9. The method of claim 1, wherein forming a first device comprises forming the first metal layer to overlie at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, and wherein forming a flux-directing layer comprises selecting the second critical temperature to be less than the first critical temperature.

10. The method of claim 1, further comprising forming a second metal layer adjacent to the first metal layer, the second metal layer comprising a shielding structure that shields the first device, the second metal layer comprising a superconducting material having a third critical temperature.

11. The method of claim 10, wherein forming a flux-directing layer comprising a second superconducting material includes providing a relative temperature difference between the second critical temperature and the third critical temperature to direct flux away from the first device and trap flux in the flux-trapping location.

12. The method of claim 11, wherein forming a first device comprises forming the first metal layer to overlie at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, and wherein forming a flux-directing layer comprises selecting the second critical temperature to be less than the third critical temperature.

13. The method of claim 9, further comprising forming one or more additional superconducting metal layers overlying at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, the critical temperature of each of the one or more additional superconducting metal layers being greater than the second critical temperature.

14. The method of claim 13, wherein forming a first metal layer, forming one or more additional superconducting metal layers, and forming a flux-directing layer includes selecting a respective critical temperature of each layer to increase incrementally by layer from the flux-directing layer to an uppermost layer of the first metal layer and the one or more additional superconducting metal layers.

15. The method of claim 1, wherein forming the flux-directing layer comprising a second superconducting material comprises forming a flux-directing layer overlying at least a portion of the first metal layer.

16. The method of claim 15, further comprising forming a second metal layer, the first metal layer overlying at least a portion of the second metal layer, the second metal layer comprising a shielding structure that shields the first device, the second metal layer comprising a superconducting material having a third critical temperature, and further comprising forming a base metal layer, the second metal layer overlying the base metal layer, the third critical temperature being greater than the critical temperature of the base metal layer, and the critical temperature of the base metal layer being greater than the second critical temperature.

17. The method of claim 15, wherein forming a flux-directing layer using a second superconducting material comprises selecting the second critical temperature to be greater than the first critical temperature.
18. The method of any one of claim 16 or claim 17, wherein forming a flux directing layer includes forming flux-trapping structures overlying at least a portion of the flux-trapping location.
19. The method of claim 18, wherein forming flux-trapping structures includes forming at least one moat.
20. The method of claim 1, further comprising forming a second device within the flux-trapping location.
21. The method of claim 20, wherein forming a second device within the flux trapping location comprises forming a digital to analog converter.
22. The method of claim 1, wherein forming a flux-directing layer comprising a second superconducting material comprises forming a flux-directing layer comprising a high kinetic inductance material.
23. The method of claim 22, further comprising forming at least one moat in the flux-directing layer.

24. A superconducting integrated circuit comprising:a first device, the first device comprising at least a portion of a first metal layer within the superconducting integrated circuit, the first metal layer comprising a first superconducting material having a first critical temperature;a flux-trapping location spaced from the first device, the flux-trapping location positioned such that flux trapped within the flux-trapping location is isolated from the first device; anda flux-directing layer comprising a superconducting material having a second critical temperature, the flux-directing layer positioned in communication with the flux-trapping location;wherein the first critical temperature and the second critical temperature have a relative temperature difference, such that as the superconducting integrated circuit is cooled to a temperature that is less than both the first critical temperature and the second critical temperature, flux is directed away from the first device and into the flux-directing layer, and the flux-directing layer directs and traps flux within the flux-trapping location.
25. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, further comprising a flux-trapping aperture at the flux-trapping location.

26. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 25, wherein the flux-trapping aperture comprises one of a parallel-piped opening and a trough positioned within the superconducting integrated circuit.
27. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, further comprising shielding that encloses the flux-trapping location.
28. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 27, wherein the shielding comprises a plurality of superconducting stud vias.
29. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 25, wherein the flux-directing layer comprises an opening aligned with the flux-trapping aperture.
30. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, wherein the first device comprises one of a qubit and a coupler.

31. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, wherein the first metal layer overlies at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, and wherein the first critical temperature is greater than the second critical temperature.

32. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, further comprising a second metal layer positioned adjacent to the first metal layer, the second metal layer comprising a shielding structure that shields the first device, the second metal layer comprising a superconducting material having a third critical temperature.

33. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 32, wherein the relative temperature difference between the second critical temperature and the third critical temperature is selected to direct flux away from the first device and into the flux-trapping location.

34. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 32, wherein the first metal layer overlies at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, and wherein the second critical temperature is less than the third critical temperature.

35. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 31, further comprising one or more additional metal layers overlying at least a portion of the flux-directing layer, a critical temperature of each additional metal layer being greater than the second critical temperature.

36. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 35, wherein the critical temperatures of the first metal layer, the one or more additional metal layers, and the flux-directing layer increase incrementally by layer from the flux-directing layer to an uppermost layer of the first metal layer and the one or more additional metal layers.
37. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, wherein the flux-directing layer overlies at least a portion of the first metal layer.

38. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 37, further comprising a second metal layer, the first metal layer overlying at least a portion of the second metal layer, the second metal layer comprising a shielding structure that shields the first device, the second metal layer comprising a superconducting material having a third critical temperature, and further comprising forming a base metal layer, the second metal layer overlying the base metal layer, the third critical temperature being greater than the critical temperature of the base metal layer, and the critical temperature of the base metal layer being greater than the second critical temperature.
39. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 37, wherein the first critical temperature is less than the second critical temperature.

40. The superconducting integrated circuit of any one of claim 38 or 39, wherein the flux-directing layer comprises flux-trapping structures overlying at least a portion of the flux-trapping location.
41. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 40, wherein the flux-trapping structures include at least one moat.
42. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, wherein the flux-trapping location contains a second device.
43. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 42, wherein the second device is a digital to analog converter.
44. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 24, wherein the flux-directing layer comprises high kinetic inductance material.
45. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 44, wherein the flux directing layer further comprises at least one moat.
46. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 44, wherein at least 10% of energy stored in the high kinetic inductance material is stored as kinetic inductance.
47. The superconducting integrated circuit of claim 44, wherein a kinetic inductance fraction of the high kinetic inductance material is 0.1<α≤1.
